contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Zblan transmit.jpg|thumb|Light attenuation by ZBLAN]] [[Image:Zblangrowth.jpg|thumb|ZBLAN produced with the same test-setup in zero-gravity (left; aboard a [[KC-135 Stratotanker|KC-135]] plane) and in normal gravity (right)]] Heavy metal [[fluoride glass]]es were accidentally discovered in 1975 by Poulain and Lucas at the University of Rennes in France,<ref>{{cite journal|doi =10.1016/0025-5408(75)90106-3|title =Verres fluores au tetrafluorure de zirconium proprietes optiques d'un verre dope au Nd3+|year =1975|author =Poulain, M|journal =Materials Research Bulletin|volume =10|pages =243|last2 =Poulain|first2 =M|last3 =Lucas|first3 =J|issue =4}}</ref> including a family of glasses '''ZBLAN''' with a composition '''Z'''rF<sub>4</sub>-'''B'''aF<sub>2</sub>-'''L'''aF<sub>3</sub>-'''A'''lF<sub>3</sub>-'''N'''aF. ZBLAN has a broad optical transmission window extending from 0.3 micrometers in the UV to 7 micrometers in the infrared, low refractive index (1.50), a relatively low glass transition temperature (''T''<sub>g</sub>) of 260 °C, low [[dispersion (optics)|dispersion]] and a low and negative ''dn''/''dT'' (temperature dependence of refractive index).<ref name="rutg">{{cite web |url=http://irfibers.rutgers.edu/pdf_files/ir_fiber_review.pdf |format=PDF |title=Infrared Fiber Optics |publisher=[[Rutgers University]] |last=Harrington |first=James A.}}</ref> ZBLAN glass is the most stable fluoride glass known and is most commonly used to make into optical fiber. Recent advances by ZBLAN fiber manufacturers have demonstrated significant increases in mechanical properties (>100 kpsi or 700 MPa for 125 µm fiber) and attenuation as low as 3 dB/km at 2.6 µm. ZBLAN optical fibers are used in different applications such as spectroscopy and sensing, laser power delivery and fiber lasers and amplifiers. The advantages of ZBLAN over other glasses, such as [[silica]], is superior infrared transmittance. Their drawbacks are fragility and sensitivity to moisture. ZBLAN glass resistance to water depends strongly on the acidity of the aqueous solution. Acidic solutions will attack it, whereas basic solutions will have no effect.<ref>{{cite journal| title = Corrosion of uranium IV fluoride glasses in aqueous solutions| author =Guery, J., Chen, D. G., Simmons, C. J., Simmons, J. H., and Jcoboni, C. | year =1988| journal = Phys. Chem. Glasses |volume = 29 | pages =30–36}}</ref> Atmospheric moisture has a very limited effect on fluoride glasses in general, and fluoride glass/fibers can be used in a wide range of operating environments over extended periods of time without any material degradation.<ref>K. Fujiura, K. Hoshino, T. Kanamori, Y. Nishida, Y. Ohishi, S. Sudo, Technical Digest of Optical Amplifiers and Their Applications, Davos, Switzerland. 15–17 June 1995 (Optical Society of America, Washington DC, USA, 1995)</ref> A large variety of multicomponent fluoride glasses have been fabricated but few can be drawn into optical fiber. The fiber fabrication is similar to any glass-fiber drawing technology. All methods involve fabrication from the melt, which creates inherent problems such as the formation of bubbles, core-clad interface irregularities, and small preform sizes. The process occurs at 310 °C in a controlled atmosphere (to minimize contamination by moisture or oxygen impurities which significantly weaken the fiber) using a narrow heat zone compared to silica.<ref name="rutg"/> Drawing is complicated by a small difference (only 124 °C) between the glass transition temperature and the crystallization temperature. As a result, ZBLAN fibers often contain undesired crystallites. Their concentration can be reduced by growing ZBLAN in zero gravity (see figure) which reduces convection processes.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://science.nasa.gov/newhome/headlines/msad05feb98_1.htm| title = ZBLAN continues to show promise| date = February 5, 1998| accessdate = 2009-06-06| publisher = [[NASA]]}}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Glass science}} [[Category:Non-oxide glasses]] [[Category:Optical materials]] [[Category:Zirconium compounds]] [[Category:Lanthanum compounds]] [[Category:Barium compounds]] [[Category:Aluminium compounds]] [[Category:Fluorides]] {{Glass-material-stub}}
